Idiom (Northern Sotho): Ngwana yo o sa llang o swarwa ke botshego.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; declarative; subject–relative clause structure.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person who does not speak up will not get help.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: If you do not ask for help, no one will help you.
Usage Contexts: Daily speech, advice, family, moral teaching.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Northern Sotho proverb emphasizing self-advocacy.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: ŋwana jɔ ɔ sa ɬaŋ ɔ sʷarʷa ke bʊt͡ʃʰɛɣɔ
First Example Sentence: Mma o mpotše gore ngwana yo o sa llang o swarwa ke botshego, ke swanetše go bolela ka mathata a ka.
Second Example Sentence: Bana ba tshwanetse go tseba gore ngwana yo o sa llang o swarwa ke botshego.
Third Example Sentence: Ge o khutsa, batho ba tla nagana gore o lokile — ngwana yo o sa llang o swarwa ke botshego.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Tau ya hloka seboka e a hlotšwa.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Passive clause; subject + auxiliary + passive verb.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person without support will fail.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancient Sotho proverb referring to lions hunting in groups.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: taʊ ja ɬɔka sɛbɔka e a ɬot͡ʃʷa
First Example Sentence: Re swanetše go šoma mmogo hobane tau ya hloka seboka e a hlotšwa.
Second Example Sentence: Matsatsing a lehono, kgwebo e hloka tšhomišano; tau ya hloka seboka e a hlotšwa.
Third Example Sentence: Batswadi ba ruta bana gore tau ya hloka seboka e a hlotšwa.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Pelo e bose ke lerumo la go hlaba mong wa yona.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex metaphorical clause with possessive phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Jealousy or hatred harms the person who feels it.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Bitterness hurts the one who holds it.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional moral wisdom emphasizing emotional control.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: pɛlɔ e bɔsɛ ke lɛrʊmɔ la ɣʊ ɬaba mʊŋ wa jɔna
First Example Sentence: Mohlologadi o gopola mantšu ao, pelo e bose ke lerumo la go hlaba mong wa yona.
Second Example Sentence: Ga o swanela go tswara lehufa; pelo e bose ke lerumo la go hlaba mong wa yona.
Third Example Sentence: Thuto ya setšo e ruta bana gore pelo e bose ke lerumo la go hlaba mong wa yona.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Mokgobo wa mollo o tsebja ka mosi.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A person is known by their deeds.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in traditional communal observation of behavior.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: mʊk͡ʰɡɔbɔ wa mʊllɔ ɔ t͡sʼɛbja ka mʊsi
First Example Sentence: Batho ba tla go tseba ka ditiro tša gago; mokgobo wa mollo o tsebja ka mosi.
Second Example Sentence: Mokgobo wa mollo o tsebja ka mosi — ditiro di bolela kudu go feta mantšu.
Third Example Sentence: Ge o dira gabotse, batho ba a go hlompha; mokgobo wa mollo o tsebja ka mosi.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Pitsi e kgolo e hlwa e na le dikgala.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common rural saying from Limpopo; references horse breeding.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: pit͡si e kʼɡɔlɔ e ɬʷa e na le dikʼɡala
First Example Sentence: Le ge e le mogolo, o ka dira diphošo; pitsi e kgolo e hlwa e na le dikgala.
Second Example Sentence: Mošomi yo mogolo o dirile phoso; ke nnete gore pitsi e kgolo e hlwa e na le dikgala.
Third Example Sentence: Mohlomphegi o tshega a re pitsi e kgolo e hlwa e na le dikgala.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Mosegare ga o robale, o ruta manong.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you neglect your duties, others will take advantage.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural metaphor; day workers must stay alert.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: mʊsɛɡarɛ ɣa ɔ rʊbalɛ ɔ rʊta manʊŋ
First Example Sentence: Tšea mošomo wa gago ka tlhokomelo; mosegare ga o robale, o ruta manong.
Second Example Sentence: Mošomi yo o sa šomeng o lahlegelwa ke ditšhelete; mosegare ga o robale, o ruta manong.
Third Example Sentence: Batswadi ba ruta bana ba bona gore mosegare ga o robale, o ruta manong.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Metsi a tšhuma a hlatswa ditšhila.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: mɛt͡si a t͡ʃʰʊma a ɬat͡sʷa dit͡ʃʰʰila
First Example Sentence: Ge re bolela nnete, re aga tshepho; metsi a tšhuma a hlatswa ditšhila.
Second Example Sentence: Ba ile ba rarolla kgohlano ka nnete; metsi a tšhuma a hlatswa ditšhila.
Third Example Sentence: Thuto ya setšo e ruta bana gore metsi a tšhuma a hlatswa ditšhila.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A reckless person faces danger head-on.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From Sotho oral storytelling; depicts impulsive behavior.
First Example Sentence: O tšwela pele le bothata bjoo; lehlanya le lebagane le meetse.
Second Example Sentence: Batswadi ba mo gopotša gore lehlanya le lebagane le meetse.
Third Example Sentence: Ka gae re bolela ka yena re re lehlanya le lebagane le meetse.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Hard times are followed by better ones.

Idiom (Northern Sotho): Mogwera wa nnete o bonagala ka mathata.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: True friendship is proven in difficult times.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A true friend helps during hardship.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pan-Sotho proverb about loyalty and community.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Northern So: mʊɣʷɛra wa n͡nɛtʼɛ ɔ bɔnagaːla ka matʰata
First Example Sentence: Ke leboga thušo ya gago; mogwera wa nnete o bonagala ka mathata.
Second Example Sentence: Mošomi yo o nthušitše ge ke be ke le bothateng; mogwera wa nnete o bonagala ka mathata.
Third Example Sentence: Re ithuta gore mogwera wa nnete o bonagala ka mathata.
